item.content:encoded: What's especially frustrating about Musk making it seem as if millions of Social Security checks might be going out to people aged 100+ is that we know how many Social Security checks went out in December to people aged 99+: 89,106.

item.content:encoded: Another profitable company (Southwest Airlines) announces mass layoffs, in an effort to appease Wall Street. Firing workers *outside of a downturn* is a breach of the social compact. Workers should share in the upside when employers are profitable; instead, they are cut loose.

item.content:encoded: And here's the number of RECIPIENTS of social security in each age bucket with the death field set to false (and recipient set to true). A mere 89,106 are aged 99+, not the tens of millions suggested by @elonmusk.

item.content:encoded: In 2024, the semiconductor foundry industry added $22B+ incremental revenue. Of that, TSMC alone added around $21B. SMIC is another company that added $1.7B in incremental revenue. Intel and GlobalFoundries each shaved off over half a billion dollar in revenue in CY24.

item.content:encoded: Opportunity to plug one of my favourite books. In the late 1700s, rapid economic progress meant that - for the first time in human history - ending poverty was conceivable. The idea that poverty no longer had to be an inevitable part of society had huge ramifications‚Ä¶

item.content:encoded: Apparently, one of the most effective ways to improve LLM performance is just to manually insert the word ‚Äúwait‚Äù at the end of every answer, to force it to think harder You have to admit, sometimes working on LLMs feels less like engineering and more like a wizard casting spells

item.content:encoded: Eggs and coffee around 20 percent more expensive. Airplanes crashing. Mass layoffs. Tariffs. Data breaches. Shutting down energy projects. Letting food and medicine rot. Either they are really shitty at helping you, or you are not the one they want to help.
